testimony: Mr Bongweni, just indicate to us if your headset is working.  Do you hear the interpreters?
I can hear, but no properly.
Alright we'll assist you.  Will you please stand to take the oath.  Are you full names Zandisile Edwin Bongweni?
Thank you, you may sit down.  Ms Dambuza.

Thank you, Mr Chairperson.
	Mr Bongweni, are you an applicant in terms of Section 18 and 20 of Act 34/95?
Which acts are you actually applying for amnesty in respect of?
It is because I was involved in the group that planned the coup.
Who approached you to be involved in this planned coup?
What did he say to you, Bongolani Ndamase?
He said that Col Duli wanted to see me.
Did you know Col Craig Duli before Ndamase approached you?
When Bongolani Ndamase approached you as you have said, what were you employed as?
I was training the soldiers that were attending the military school.
And where exactly were you stationed?
Did Bongolani Ndamase tell you what Col Duli wanted to see you about?
No, he did not tell me.
Did you go then and see Col Duli as requested?
Ndamase was driving a car, he took me with him and then we met Mxutu and Zwamadoda Ntisana and Mazizi.  We all drove to Queenstown and we met with him in Queenstown, that is Col Duli.
What did Col Duli tell you when you met him?

Col Duli said that he wanted to see us because as we knew that the government said that it would hand over to the people's government, but that didn't happen yet, so he said that he had already met with other soldiers so we had to overthrow Mr Holomisa's government.
We said that we had wanted that to happen because Gen Holomisa had promised that the government would be returned to the people.
Were you involved in the pervious coup when the government of Ms Stella Sigcau was toppled?
What happened then after you agreed to be involved in the coup?

He told us that we must go to Port St Johns and inform the soldiers there, so that they can be aware of what was going to happen.  He said that he had already told the officers in Post St Johns, but the other soldiers were not aware of what was going to happen.
And did you go and tell them as instructed?
Yes, we told them as we were instructed.
Did the coup in fact take place?

No, it didn't take place because when we came back from Port St Johns, when we arrived here in Umtata the day before the planned coup, we were told that we had to abandon the plan and then on the following day when we were going to work we were then arrested.
And were you subsequently convicted and sentenced in respect of this deed?
Can you please repeat the question.
Were you then after your arrest, subsequently convicted and sentenced for your actions?
Yes, I was convicted and sentenced to 8 years, 4 years suspended.
How many years did you serve and when were you released?
I served four years and I was released in 1994, end of November 1994.
When you met Col Duli in Queenstown, was Mr Mxutu in the same meeting?
And what part were you going to play, you yourself, in the intended coup?
I was going to talk with the soldiers, inform them about what was going to happen, so that there could be no conflict.
Did you foresee any bloodshed or even loss of life when you were planning this coup?
No, there was nothing like that because Col Duli said that he had informed all the officers, they were aware of what was going to happen.
Are you now applying that the Committee grants you amnesty for your acts as you've just outlined?
Yes, I would like the Committee to give me amnesty for my actions.

Mr Chairman, that is the evidence.
NO FURTHER QUESTIONS BY MS DAMBUZA
Thank you, Ma'am.  Mr Nodada, questions?
Mr Bongweni, by the way where were you based as a solider at the time?
And how were you going to inform the members of the special forces at Port St Johns about this intended coup?
We would meet with them in Port St Johns and tell them, those that were the same level of ranks with us, that Col Duli had told us to inform them, as we indeed did so, we told them.
Did he tell you how you should actually go about telling them, namely whether you should call a meeting of all of them and announce this, or how did he say you must actually inform them?
He told us that we should meet with some few members that were in the same ranks as ourselves and tell them.
Did he give you the assurance that most of the soldiers were in favour of the coup that he was planning?
Yes, that is correct, he gave is the assurance.
You have said in your evidence you did not expect that there would be bloodshed, why did you not expect it if it was going to be as planned by Col Duli?
It is because he said that he had met with the soldiers, they were aware of what was going to happen, so there was not going to be any conflict.
What did he say about these senior officers, that is senior members of the TDF?
He said that he had already met with all of the senior members of the TDF, they were aware of this and they were supporting him.
Yes, I believe that because there was nothing that could make me not to believe it.
Did you also share the feeling that the military council that was ruling at the time should be overthrown?
Yes, I also shared that feeling because I thought that it would be better if the government was ruled by the civilians.
And you know now what actually happened, how the whole coup was carried out and when it was actually stage in November later that year.
No, I don't know how it happened.
Now do you consider yourself responsible directly or indirectly, for the loss of life as well as the loss of limb that was occasioned by the aborted coup of 22 November 1990?
No, because I was already in jail at the time.
So you do not consider yourself responsible for that?
You do not consider yourself responsible for that ultimate ...(intervention)
No, no, because I was not there, I was not involved.
Now why are you applying for amnesty, what do you want to be pardoned for?
Because I was sentenced and I have a criminal record, so I would like that to be removed because I cannot even get employment, I can't do anything.
Why must it be removed, why do you want it removed?
Because I was involved in the group that was planning this coup.

Mr Nodada, do you intend to call some witnesses?
Yes, Mr Chairman.  That is correct Mr Chairman.

I'll start with the one next to me.
Alright, let's set the thing up quickly.
Thank you, Mr Chairman.  I'm calling Themba Pokwana, who is going to testify as one of the victims of this aborted coup on 22 November 1990.  May he be sworn in please.
Certainly Mr Nodada.  Mr Pokwana, just indicate to us if your headset is working, whether you can hear the interpreters talking to you.
You must please stand to take the oath. Are your full names Themba Pokwana?
Thank you, you may sit down.  Mr Nodada.
Themba, during 1990, were you a member of the Transkei Defence Force?
In 1990 I was a recruit in Ncise.
A recruit in the Transkei Defence Force?
And you were based at Ncise, where you were undergoing your initial training.
Right.  Were you present at the camp where you were accommodated on the night of 21 November 1990?
I want you to cast you memories back to the events of that evening and actually give a full account of what you experienced on that night.

What happened is on the 21st until the 22nd of November 1990, we were sleeping as the recruits. At about 3 o'clock in the morning we heard some noise outside.  After hearing that noise out side some of us woke up because we were staying there in the camp, in the bungalows.
Just slow down a bit.  Carry on.
After that almost all of us woke up, we heard outside that there was noises of some gunshots.
What noise - oh gunshots.  Was that the only noise that you heard outside, gunshots being fired?
Yes, at first it was only the gunshots.
And what was your immediate reaction when you heard those gunshots?
As we were sleeping we woke up and we dressed up.
Were you all sleeping in the same sort of a dormitory or how were you sleeping?  Were you in different rooms?
Some of us were sleeping in a bungalow like a dormitory.
Others were in other houses, others were in the tents.
But you were within the same premises, all of you.
After getting dressed I saw a man by the name of Kwele, he had blood on his face.
Were the lights on inside when you woke up?
Yes, because we had already woken up, all of us.
So this man by the name of Kwele, was he entering the bungalow in which you were gathered after you had woken up?
Yes, he was entering the bungalow that I was in.

He went in and he was bleeding heavily in his face.  When I stood up, next to me was Mr Peter, the deceased Mr Peter.  He was still alive at the time.  And when I was standing up I could hear that there were some movements and it was at that the time when the bomb was thrown inside the bungalow.  I then got injured that way.
Were you armed as you were sleeping in the bungalow?
No, we had nothing, we were not armed.
After you had been injured, were you able to see what followed after the event?
Because it was still dark, at about three or four when this bomb was thrown inside, the lights went off.  After that I didn't know what happened.
Were you unconscious or was it just dark?
After being injured I became unconscious.
And when did you regain consciousness and where were you?
I became conscious and I was still in the bungalow, at about 6 a.m. on the 22nd.
And what part of your body was injured?
In the head, face and in my body and both legs.
What did you see when you regained consciousness at about 6 o'clock?
When I regained consciousness I saw Mr Peter and he was sleeping where he was sleeping and the deceased Mr Gungu too, the people that I was staying with in the bungalow and they were dead.
And were there any casualties that you saw in the same vicinity, other than the two dead persons?
Yes, I also saw Nomganga, I saw the man behind me, Nombida and the others that were also in that bungalow and Mr Mogoduga who is not there now.  They were all injured.
And what was happening at that time?
At that time it was noise outside, I think it was when these people that were with Col Duli were arriving.  I don't know what was happening outside because I was inside, it was just noises outside.
What sort of noise was that, was it human noise or noise of fired guns or bombing, what noise was it? - as you could make out.
It was gunshots and people's voices, they were calling others.
Yes, and then after that what happened?
After that at about seven or after 7 o'clock, soldiers came that were trying to help us, those that were working in that recruit camp.
Did they take you to hospital?

Yes, they took us out outside and when we were outside we were supposed to be taken by an ambulance and then we realised that the group that was with Col Duli had arrived and then these people that were going to help us, they ran away trying to save their lives and they left us outside.
And these people that you say were coming with Craig Duli, that you saw when you got outside, what were they doing? - as far as you could make out.
As I was already injured and I was outside, I could only see people that were going to the other camp known as 1TBM.
Were you sitting - I mean, how did the soldiers who were helping, leave you outside, did they just leave you on the ground or where were you left?

They took us out of the bungalow, we were wrapped in blankets, so they left us like that.  The reason why they decided to leave us is because another bomb was thrown when they were busy taking us outside, so they ran away.
Was it thrown at the place where you were left, or inside some building?
This bomb was thrown in the road, because there was a road in-between, so they put us on the side where the tents were.
So you were not affected by that bomb?

Sorry, Mr Nodada.
	Was it a bomb or a handgrenade, or don't you know?
It was a mortar bomb, not a handgrenade.
On both occasions, the one that was thrown into the bungalow and also the one when you were being carried out?
Yes, they were both mortar bombs.
Yes, thank you.  Sorry, Mr Nodada.

Thank you.
	Did that one explode, the last one that you have just mentioned?
Yes, it exploded and its shrapnel went to the sides of the bungalows, not on our side.
So nobody was injured as far as you know, as a result of that?
I can't remember well because I was on the other side with others that were injured, so I don't know about the people that were in the bungalows because there were a lot of bungalows there.
You have described these people that you saw outside, those that caused the group that was helping you, as Duli group, did you know that they were Duli group at that time, or you were just confused?
Because of the uniform they had it was clear that it was not the soldiers that were working with us, it was clear that they were the attackers.
Were they dressed in combat uniform, or how were they dressed?
Those that I saw were wearing coco-brown, not the Transkeian Defence Force uniform.
This coco-brown uniform, did you recognise it to be belonging to any military group or liberation army?  How did you understand this coco-brown uniform?
It was being used by the SADF.
So in short you saw people who were dressed in the South African Defence Force uniform?
Did you recognise anyone of them at that stage?
Alright.  Now you saw them going up to the other camps and then, carry on and tell us what you saw.

After that as we were being left there and the soldiers ran away after this second bomb had exploded, I noticed some people like Mr Mlandeli, a deceased, and Mr Mzweni, they were already dead.  And after some time the soldiers came back, they took me to the military hospital.
And did you ever see those soldiers who were dressed in the SADF uniform, after you had seen them going up in the direction you've indicated?
No, I didn't see them after that.
And then you landed in hospital?
Yes, I was taken to the hospital.
And while you were in hospital did you see anything else that apparently was connected with those acts?
No, I did not see anything.
And for how long did you remain in hospital?
I remained there in the morning and I was taken at about three and I was transferred to the general hospital here in Umtata.
On the same day, that is 22 November?
And when did you first hear that these were soldiers, or these were persons who were aiding Col Duli to overthrow the military council government?
As I've already indicated, as we heard those bombs and there was a person who was speaking in a loudspeaker saying that he was Col Duli and he was back.
Yes, and then after you had been discharged from the hospital, did you go back to the base where you were being trained as a recruit?
Yes, I went back to the base where I was being trained.
Are you now still working as a soldier?
Right.  Did you get any compensation for the injuries that you sustained?
No, I didn't get any compensation.
I've no further questions, Mr Chairperson.
Sorry Mr Nodada, just while you're on that point, I don't know if you've done it already but it would be appreciated if you could give a list of the victims that you are representing to Mr Mapoma.

Because we as a Committee, in the event of any amnesty being granted or in the event of a gross violation, are bound to refer the victims through to the Committee on Reparations and Rehabilitation and having a list also enabling that Committee to be able to track down and trace the victims would be appreciated.

Thank you, Mr Chairman.

	Mr Nombida, just indicate to us if your headset is working, if you can hear the interpreters.
Will you please stand to take the oath.  Are your names Zola Nombida.
Thank you, you may sit down.  Yes, Mr Nodada.
Zola, what are you doing for a living now?
I'm a soldier, Air Force in Pretoria.
And were you a member of the Transkei Defence Force in 1990?
Yes, I was a member of the Transkei Defence Force in 1990, I was a recruit.
Were you in the same group as the last witness, Mr Pokwana?
Were you in the same camp on the night or early morning of the 22nd of November 1990?
Yes, I was in the same camp, we were in the same bungalow with Mr Pokwana.
Yes.  What happened as far as you can remember?
In the morning, 22nd November 1990, round about 3 o'clock, early in the morning we heard gunshots outside and immediately after that we put the lights on and then we dressed up.
Not all of us at the same time, some of use woke up and then some were dressing up because that was a big bungalow, there was more than 80 of us, but most of us had already woken up at the time.
Yes, you woke after hearing gunfires outside, and then what happened?

After that Mr Kwele went in and his fact was full of blood, he was bleeding, we then asked what was happening, he then went to the other side of the bungalow, he went straight to the other side.  We asked one another what was happening, his face was full of blood.
Did he tell you what was happening?
He just said that there was shooting outside.
Had he been sleeping in the same bungalow as you and Pokwana?
No, he was not in that bungalow, he was sleeping in the tent because we were sleeping according to the different companies.  We were in D company and he was in E company on the site of the tents.
Yes, and then what happened afterwards?
What happened after Mr Kwele went in, we heard that there was shooting going on outside.  Immediately after that this mortar bomb from the roof exploded.
Yes, and what happened, did you get injured?
Yes, I got injured.  There was noise going on and the cries in the bungalow.  We were injured and there was confusion all over.  I was also injured.
Yes, were you able to see anything immediately after you had been injured?

Yes, I was able to see everything that was happening because I was not unconscious, I was hit here on the waist and on my leg, so I was able to see what was happening because I was just shocked but I didn't become unconscious.
Now did you also hear some voices after the bomb?

I heard the voices when the soldiers came, those that saved us from the bungalow, those that took us outside.  And they took us to a place outside, we were covered with blankets.  From there another bomb, the second one, a mortar bomb exploded and those people that were helping us said that those who can manage to run away must run away and they left us there.  I managed to crawl and go to another tent, trying to hide away from what was happening.  I was with another young man, Nomganga.  We went inside that tent, hiding.
It is where I heard voices when I was in that tent.
I heard somebody speaking from a loudspeaker outside saying that he was Col Duli, he said that we must stand in a queue in the camp.
Did you see any other soldiers who were not injured, outside at that stage?
Those who were able to run away, they managed to run away but others were taken to the hospitals with the ambulance, those that were injured.
Yes.  In other words, there was just a chaos that you witnessed outside.
Alright, that continued until what happened?

After hiding in that tent we heard rifles outside and the mortar bombs continued.  What I could recognise is that in that cover I was injured when I was going there and there were people that were wearing coco-brown uniforms.  They were next to the fence in our camp, those were the people that I recognised.
Were there any moving motor vehicles or trucks in that area at the time?

No, those people were standing next to the fence, seemingly it was clear that they are the ones that were shooting in the camp because they were wearing coco-brown uniforms and in the Transkei Defence Force we were not using coco-brown uniforms at the time.
Did you also know that uniform to be the South African Defence Force uniform?
Yes, I knew that it was the South African Defence Force uniform.

Whilst I was still in the tent there was chaos outside and I could hear the person who was speaking and it was going towards the morning and the soldiers that were going to save us, they came and we were in the tent, they went inside the tent.  They were the ones who organised transport for us to take us to the hospital.
	At that time there was no ambulance, they took me with a motor vehicle that belonged to a bakery and took me to the junction.  When I arrived at the junction I was taken to another car that was driven by the deceased Sgt-Maj Boni.  I was taken by that car and then I was escorted by two people, they took me to the general hospital.
You are describing Sgt-Maj Boni as deceased, did he also die on the same day?
No, didn't die on that day, he died afterwards due to some illness, after the coup.
How many persons did you see dead on that morning, before you landed in hospital?
Three of them died in that bungalow, Mr Cgonguto, Olyai and Peter.  Three of them died in that bungalow, two died in the tents, Mr Zweli and Mr Mlangeni.
And in hospital were there any of those that were injured that died?
No, nobody died in hospital, but most of us were taken to the intensive care unit.
Yes.  What part of your body was injured?
My waist and my right leg and my left side.
Were you shot or were you injured as a result of the bomb that was thrown into the bungalow?
I was injured due to the bomb that was thrown in the bungalow.
Alright.  And you subsequently learnt that that was Craig Duli's group that was attempting to stage a coup d'etat to take over the government of this place from the military council, is that so?

Yes, that is correct, and that was also confirmed when I was in the intensive care unit.  When Gen Matanzima arrived, he gave us the information, he told us what was happening.  He said that Mr Duli had staged a coup.
Apart from you soldiers that were based at Ncise camp, did you see any other persons who did not belong to the TDF, that were killed or injured in the same area?
According to me I don't know anything of that sort because I only know the recruits that died and then I was taken to the hospital.
Did you know that there was going to be an attack that evening, or that morning?
Did you know that Col Duli was planning to overthrow the military government during the year 1990?
No, I didn't know anything at all.
Have you received any compensation for the injuries that you sustained, Sir?
What is your rank now as a member of the SANDF in the ...(indistinct)
Is there anything else that you'd like to inform this Committee about?

What I can say to this Committee is that as we sustained injuries there it is very difficult to advance ourselves in the military and some of us left the military because they were injured.  Even myself, it is very difficult for me to do certain courses because they require physical training, but because I was injured I am unable to do that.  That is what I can say to this Committee.
Thank you, Mr Nodada.  Mr Malan?

I've got no questions to pose, thank you, Sir.

	Nosisi, are you the widow of Nedisi Atwell Kahla?
Was he employed by the Transkei Defence Force?
And is it correct that he died on the same day, that is the morning of the 22nd of November 1990?
Where was he based during his lifetime?
He was in Ncise camp as the instructor for the recruits.
And what was his rank, if you know?
And where were you working at the time, if you were employed?
I was working for Telkom as a telephonist.
And was he living outside the camp or was he residing at the camp, that is your husband?
Sometimes he would be inside the camp as a training officer for the recruits, but on that particular night he was in the camp.
In the camp.  And what did you hear on the 22nd of November and where were you?
I was at work at the post office that night, I was on duty.
Just tell us how you got to know that your husband had died.

On that particular night, on the morning of the 22nd, we left our workplace, some technicians came and they realised that something was going on in the camp at about 3a.m.  We were requested and the other people were requested to come and assist because the people inside at work were not supposed to go out, we help in communications.
	I continued on duty up until 11 and 12a.m. because people were not allowed to come in and those who were inside were not allowed to go out.

We were later released at about one.  I was residing next to Chatham.  In fact on that particular morning I asked the other soldiers who were going to the camp to go and check out for Mlungisi.  No-one came back to me to tell me what was happening until such time that I had to go home.
	After that I decided to go out to check up on him because he was at work on that particular night, but I did not get a clue of what was happening.  And I called Mr Derek Mgwebi, Mr Mgwebi told me to stay in the house, he was going to check what was happening and then I also called Brig Matanzima, he told me that he would come back to me but he requested me to remain in the house, they would come and fetch me because Mlungisi was injured.
	I waited until the following day but no-one came.  I phoned my brother, the deceased DM and I told him that no-one came back to me to tell me what was happening to Mlungisi and I asked him to accompany me to the camp.  When we got to the road junction there were roadblocks, we could not get into the camp in time but eventually we managed to get inside.  I went to his office that was called "Skollie", I met with the late Andile Mncwazi, he told me that Mlungisi was injured, but he did not tell me that he had died. 
	When we left him all the people who knew me they did not even want to look at me.  Rev Lila came and asked me where I was going and I told him that I was looking for Mlungisi, I wanted to know what was happening because when we went to the hospital to see the casualties we were refused.  Rev Lila told me to go to Lebode to go and fetch my mother because Mlungisi was injured.  He told us that we could not go to the hospital without an elderly person.  Mr Lila told my mother that Mlungisi was injured and he died in the process.  That's how I know the story.
And how many children did you have at the time of his death?
Two children, two daughters.  The first-born was four years old and the last-born was one year old.
And since his death have you perhaps received any form of compensation for the loss of maintenance and support as he was the breadwinner in your house?
Yes, I am receiving a widow's fund plus what is called Workmen's Compensation.

Nothing.  Thank you Mr Chairman, that's all I wanted to lead from this witness.

	Mr Chairman and Members of the Committee, at the start of the proceedings yesterday I didn't feel at liberty to disclose some of the views, due to the fact that I felt it might prejudice my clients' applications.
